title: 1 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 9.

questions.question: What did the LORD say He had done concerning the house Solomon built?
options: Hallowed this house to put His name there forever
Destroyed the house because of sin
Given the house to another king
questions.correctAnswer: Hallowed this house to put His name there forever
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:3 states that the LORD said He has hallowed the house Solomon built to put His name there forever.

questions.question: Who appeared to Solomon the second time after he finished building the house of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:2 says the LORD appeared to Solomon the second time, as He had at Gibeon.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 9:5, what will God establish if Solomon walks before Him in integrity and keeps His statutes?
options: The throne of Solomon's kingdom upon Israel forever
A great army to conquer all nations
questions.correctAnswer: The throne of Solomon's kingdom upon Israel forever
questions.explanation: God promises in 1 Kings 9:5 to establish Solomon's throne over Israel forever if he obeys Him.

questions.question: What will happen if Solomon or his descendants turn away from following God and serve other gods?
options: God will cut off Israel from the land He gave them
questions.correctAnswer: God will cut off Israel from the land He gave them
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:7 warns that turning away and serving other gods will cause God to cut off Israel from the land He gave them.

questions.question: How long did it take Solomon to build the house of the LORD and the king's house?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:10 states it was at the end of twenty years that Solomon had built both houses.

questions.question: Who furnished Solomon with cedar and fir trees and gold according to all his desire?
questions.correctAnswer: Hiram king of Tyre
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:11 shows that Hiram king of Tyre supplied Solomon with cedar, fir, and gold.

questions.question: What did Solomon give Hiram in return for the materials supplied?
options: Twenty cities in the land of Galilee
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty cities in the land of Galilee
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:11 records that Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in Galilee.

questions.question: How did Hiram react to the cities Solomon gave him?
questions.correctAnswer: They pleased him not
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:12 states that Hiram came to see the cities but they did not please him.

questions.question: What name did Hiram give to the cities Solomon gave him?
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Cabul
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:13 says Hiram called those cities the land of Cabul to this day.

questions.question: What was the amount of gold Hiram sent to Solomon?
questions.correctAnswer: Sixscore talents
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:14 records that Hiram sent sixscore (120) talents of gold to Solomon.

questions.question: True or False: Solomon made the children of Israel bondmen for his work.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:22 explains that Solomon did not make the children of Israel bondmen but made them men of war and officers.

questions.question: True or False: Pharaoh king of Egypt gave the city of Gezer as a present to Solomon's wife.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:16 states Pharaoh took Gezer, burned it, and gave it as a present to his daughter, Solomon's wife.

questions.question: True or False: Solomon built a navy of ships at Eziongeber on the shore of the Red Sea.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:26 confirms Solomon made a navy of ships at Eziongeber beside Eloth on the Red Sea shore.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Kings 9:25: 'And three times in a year did Solomon offer ______ and peace offerings upon the altar which he built unto the LORD.'
questions.correctAnswer: burnt offerings
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:25 specifies that Solomon offered burnt offerings and peace offerings three times a year.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 9:20-21, what kind of service did the leftover children of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites perform?
questions.correctAnswer: A tribute of bondservice
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:21 states Solomon levied a tribute of bondservice on the leftover children of these nations.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 9 teach us about the importance of obedience in maintaining God's blessings?
options: Obedience leads to God's perpetual presence and the establishment of the kingdom
Obedience has no bearing on God's blessings
God's blessings depend only on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to God's perpetual presence and the establishment of the kingdom
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:3-5 show that God promises to establish Solomon's throne forever if he walks in integrity and keeps God's statutes. Verses 9:6-7 warn that turning away will result in loss of blessing, highlighting the importance of obedience.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to serve other things besides God. Based on 1 Kings 9, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Turning from God leads to judgment and reproach among nations
God will overlook their sin without repentance
Serving other gods will bring prosperity
Temptation is a sign of God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: Turning from God leads to judgment and reproach among nations
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:6-9 clearly state that forsaking God and worshipping other gods causes God to cut off Israel from the land and make them a byword among the nations, emphasizing the consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: What does Solomon's building of the house of the LORD and his own house teach us about stewardship and work ethic?
options: Diligent work and stewardship are necessary to fulfill God’s purposes
Building projects are distractions from spiritual life
Only spiritual work matters, not physical labor
questions.correctAnswer: Diligent work and stewardship are necessary to fulfill God’s purposes
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:1, 9:10-15 show Solomon's dedication to completing God's house and his own palace, using resources wisely, and raising a levy for construction, illustrating responsible stewardship and diligent work.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 9 encourage humility and contentment in leadership?
options: Leaders must walk in integrity and obedience to maintain God’s favor
Leaders should rely on their own wisdom, not God
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must walk in integrity and obedience to maintain God’s favor
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:4-5 highlight that Solomon’s leadership is dependent on walking in integrity like David, showing humility and obedience as keys to God's continued blessing and favor.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and personal devotion is found in 1 Kings 9?
options: God hears and responds to sincere prayer and supplication
Prayer is unnecessary when building physical structures
God only listens to prayers from kings
questions.correctAnswer: God hears and responds to sincere prayer and supplication
questions.explanation: Verse 1 Kings 9:3 states that God heard Solomon’s prayer and hallowed the house Solomon built, emphasizing the power and importance of earnest prayer and devotion.

questions.question: Based on 1 Kings 9, how should a believer approach the challenge of perseverance through trials?
options: By maintaining integrity and obedience to God despite difficulties
By abandoning faith when trials occur
By relying solely on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: By maintaining integrity and obedience to God despite difficulties
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:4-7 show that God’s promises depend on obedience and integrity, implying believers must persevere faithfully even when challenged, to receive God's blessings.

questions.question: How can the account of Solomon’s naval expeditions in 1 Kings 9 inspire biblical stewardship and generosity?
options: Using resources to expand God’s kingdom and provide for others
Seeking wealth only for selfish gain
questions.correctAnswer: Using resources to expand God’s kingdom and provide for others
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:26-28 describe Solomon’s navy bringing gold from Ophir, showing wise use of resources to support the kingdom’s work, encouraging faithful stewardship and generosity.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 9, Solomon made the Israelites into bondservants.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 1 Kings 9:22 clearly states Solomon did not make the children of Israel bondmen, but they served as warriors and officials, indicating respect and honor for God's people.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD promised Solomon that if he disobeyed, the house of the LORD would be cast out of His sight.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 1 Kings 9:7 states that if Solomon or his descendants turned from God, God would cast the house He had hallowed out of His sight, warning about consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of ______.
questions.correctAnswer: Galilee
questions.explanation: Verse 1 Kings 9:11 mentions that Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilee, showing a political transaction between the kings.

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 9 teach about the consequences of forsaking God and worshipping other gods?
options: It leads to destruction and reproach among all people
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to destruction and reproach among all people
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:7-9 describe how forsaking God causes Israel to be cut off, and the house to be despised and questioned by all nations, emphasizing the seriousness of idolatry.

questions.question: How does the building of Millo and the cities described in 1 Kings 9 relate to biblical principles of diligence and planning?
options: They reflect careful preparation and diligent work to secure and build the kingdom
They show that building is unnecessary for spiritual growth
They indicate neglect of God’s instructions
questions.correctAnswer: They reflect careful preparation and diligent work to secure and build the kingdom
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:15-19 and 9:24 indicate Solomon’s careful construction efforts, reflecting biblical virtues of diligence and wise planning in fulfilling God’s purposes.

questions.question: How is the theme of integrity emphasized in 1 Kings 9 for daily living and leadership?
options: Solomon is called to walk before God in integrity of heart and uprightness
Integrity is not mentioned as important
Only outward actions matter, not integrity
Integrity guarantees worldly success without God
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon is called to walk before God in integrity of heart and uprightness
questions.explanation: Verse 1 Kings 9:4 specifically commands Solomon to walk in integrity and uprightness as David did, highlighting integrity as essential in leadership and life.

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 9 teach about the role of prayer in building God’s house and personal endeavors?
options: Prayer is essential and God honors sincere requests
Prayer is a ritual without real impact
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is essential and God honors sincere requests
questions.explanation: Verse 1 Kings 9:3 shows God responding to Solomon’s prayer and hallowing the house, teaching the importance of prayer in God’s work and personal efforts.

questions.question: Based on 1 Kings 9, how can believers apply the principle of faithfulness in their family and parenting life?
options: By walking in God’s statutes and teaching children to obey, securing blessings for generations
By ignoring God’s commands and focusing only on abundance
By relying on heritage alone without personal obedience
By allowing children to worship other gods
questions.correctAnswer: By walking in God’s statutes and teaching children to obey, securing blessings for generations
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Kings 9:4-6 emphasize obedience and faithfulness not just personally but for one’s children, showing the impact of parental guidance on God’s blessings.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 9.

questions.question: What condition did the LORD set for Solomon to establish his throne over Israel forever?
options: Walk before God with integrity and uprightness, keeping His statutes and judgments
Build more cities and expand the kingdom
Offer sacrifices three times a year as prescribed
questions.correctAnswer: Walk before God with integrity and uprightness, keeping His statutes and judgments
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:4-5 explains that if Solomon walks before God as David did, in integrity and keeping God's statutes, then God will establish his throne forever.

questions.question: How does the divine promise to Solomon in 1 Kings 9 reflect the Davidic covenant found in 2 Samuel 7?
options: God promises an everlasting throne for Solomon's descendants as He did for David
God promises Solomon wealth and military victories only
God requires Solomon to build a temple but offers no covenantal promise
God promises to exile Israel if they disobey, without mentioning David
questions.correctAnswer: God promises an everlasting throne for Solomon's descendants as He did for David
questions.explanation: The promise in 1 Kings 9:5 echoes the Davidic covenant in 2 Samuel 7, emphasizing an everlasting kingdom if obedience is maintained.

questions.question: What is the consequence mentioned in 1 Kings 9 if Solomon or his descendants turn to serve other gods?
options: Israel will be cut off from the land, and the temple will be cast out of God's sight
They will lose their wealth but keep the throne
The temple will be destroyed but Israel will remain
Only Solomon will be punished, with no effect on the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Israel will be cut off from the land, and the temple will be cast out of God's sight
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 warn that turning away will result in Israel's removal from the land and the temple losing God's favor.

questions.question: The name 'land of Cabul' given by Hiram to the cities Solomon gave him likely reflects what kind of literary device?
options: A term of endearment indicating alliance
A neutral geographic designation without connotation
questions.correctAnswer: A pejorative epithet expressing displeasure
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 9:12-13, Hiram's displeasure leads him to call the cities 'land of Cabul,' a term that suggests dissatisfaction, likely a pun or pejorative.

questions.question: What cultural or political significance might Solomon’s rebuilding of cities like Gezer and Megiddo have in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Demonstrates consolidation of control over strategic military and trade locations
Only serves as a religious function to honor God
Is a symbolic gesture without practical purpose
questions.correctAnswer: Demonstrates consolidation of control over strategic military and trade locations
questions.explanation: Verses 15-19 show Solomon building and fortifying important cities, reflecting political and military strategy common in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: How does the presence of non-Israelite populations subjected to forced labor under Solomon relate to the broader biblical theme of covenant people and outsiders?
options: Non-Israelites were subjected to tribute, while Israelites served in leadership and military roles
All peoples in the land were treated equally under Solomon
Israelites were enslaved while non-Israelites held power
There is no distinction made between Israelites and others in service roles
questions.correctAnswer: Non-Israelites were subjected to tribute, while Israelites served in leadership and military roles
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:20-22 distinguishes between non-Israelites serving as forced laborers and Israelites serving as leaders and warriors, reflecting covenantal distinctions.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the LORD’s statement that His 'eyes and heart shall be there perpetually' in the temple Solomon built?
options: It signifies divine presence and continual attention to the temple as God's dwelling place
It means God will physically dwell only in that temple
It indicates that the temple will never require repair
It implies that sacrifices will be unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies divine presence and continual attention to the temple as God's dwelling place
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:3 states that God has hallowed the house and His eyes and heart will be there perpetually, symbolizing ongoing divine presence and favor.

questions.question: Which historical figure is noted for providing Solomon with cedar and fir trees as well as gold, reflecting ancient Near Eastern diplomatic relations?
questions.correctAnswer: Hiram, king of Tyre
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:11-14 describes Hiram king of Tyre furnishing Solomon with timber and gold, highlighting international cooperation.

questions.question: What does the building of Millo, as mentioned in 1 Kings 9:15 and 24, represent in the urban development of Jerusalem?
options: Filling in or fortifying a defensive structure or area in the city
A new temple dedicated to other gods
A marketplace for trade with neighboring nations
A royal palace distinct from Solomon’s own house
questions.correctAnswer: Filling in or fortifying a defensive structure or area in the city
questions.explanation: Millo likely refers to a fortification or fill-in structure to strengthen Jerusalem’s defenses, as Solomon built it after the temple and palace.

questions.question: True or False: Solomon offered burnt offerings and peace offerings only once a year on the altar he built to the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:25 states that Solomon offered these sacrifices three times a year, not just once.

questions.question: What is the significance of the navy Solomon built at Eziongeber on the Red Sea shore in relation to Israel’s economic expansion?
options: It facilitated trade expeditions such as the voyage to Ophir for gold
It was primarily for military defense against Edom
It was used for pilgrimage transport to Egypt
It was a ceremonial fleet for religious festivals
questions.correctAnswer: It facilitated trade expeditions such as the voyage to Ophir for gold
questions.explanation: Verses 26-28 show Solomon’s navy, with Hiram's sailors, sailed to Ophir to bring back gold, highlighting trade expansion.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Solomon’s temple dedication and God’s appearance at Gibeon (1 Kings 9:2) connect to earlier biblical worship sites?
options: Gibeon was a significant high place of worship before the temple was built in Jerusalem
Gibeon was the original site of the tabernacle in the wilderness
Gibeon was only associated with pagan worship
questions.correctAnswer: Gibeon was a significant high place of worship before the temple was built in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:2 mentions God's appearance to Solomon at Gibeon, tying to earlier worship at high places before the temple's establishment.

questions.question: What is the literary function of the warning that Israel shall become a 'proverb and a byword among all people' if they forsake God?
options: A prophetic foreshadowing of Israel's exile and disgrace
A metaphor for Israel's military success
A promise of Israel’s eternal honor
An indication of no consequences for disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: A prophetic foreshadowing of Israel's exile and disgrace
questions.explanation: Verses 7-9 use this phrase to foreshadow the consequences of disobedience, including exile and loss of reputation.

questions.question: In 1 Kings 9, the term 'bondservice' used for the non-Israelite peoples likely refers to which of the following in the ancient socio-political context?
options: Forced labor or tribute under Solomon’s administration
Voluntary religious service in the temple
Diplomatic envoys sent to neighboring kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: Forced labor or tribute under Solomon’s administration
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:21 explains that the remnant non-Israelite peoples were made to provide forced labor, reflecting social hierarchies of the time.

questions.question: How does the gift of Gezer from Pharaoh to Solomon through marriage illustrate international relations in the ancient Near East?
options: It reflects political alliances sealed by marriage and territorial exchange
It was a religious dedication to the Egyptian gods
It was an act of conquest by Solomon over Egypt
It shows the rejection of Egyptian influence by Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects political alliances sealed by marriage and territorial exchange
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:16 describes Pharaoh gifting Gezer to Solomon as dowry for his daughter, highlighting diplomatic marriage alliances.

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What condition did God set for Solomon to establish his throne over Israel forever?
options: Walk before God with integrity and keep His statutes
Build more cities and expand Israel's borders
Marry foreign princesses to form alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Walk before God with integrity and keep His statutes
questions.explanation: God told Solomon that if he walked before Him as David did, in integrity and uprightness, keeping statutes and judgments, then He would establish Solomon's throne forever (1 Kings 9:4-5). This echoes God's covenant with David and the call for obedience seen throughout Scripture (Deuteronomy 28:1-2; Psalm 89:3-4; 2 Samuel 7:12-16; 1 Chronicles 28:9).

questions.question: What consequence did God declare if Solomon or his descendants turned from following Him and worshiped other gods?
options: God would cut off Israel from the land and reject the temple
They would be blessed with wealth and many children
They would be given victory over their enemies
God would send prophets to guide them back
questions.correctAnswer: God would cut off Israel from the land and reject the temple
questions.explanation: God warned that if Solomon or his children forsook Him and served other gods, He would cut off Israel from their land and cast away the temple He had hallowed, making Israel a byword among nations (1 Kings 9:6-7). This reflects covenantal curses for disobedience (Deuteronomy 28:15-68; Jeremiah 7:30-34; Ezekiel 9:6; Hosea 4:17).

questions.question: Why will people who pass by the temple be astonished and hiss according to 1 Kings 9?
options: Because the LORD forsook the land and temple due to Israel's idolatry
Because the temple was the largest building in the world
Because foreign gods were worshiped inside the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD forsook the land and temple due to Israel's idolatry
questions.explanation: The chapter states that passersby will be astonished and hiss, questioning why the LORD has done this, and the answer will be Israel's forsaking of God and worship of other gods, leading to judgment (1 Kings 9:8-9). This is consistent with prophetic warnings about the consequences of idolatry (Isaiah 65:1-7; Ezekiel 8:6-18; Jeremiah 22:9-10; Psalm 78:56-58).

questions.question: How long did it take Solomon to build the two houses mentioned in 1 Kings 9?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years
questions.explanation: The text says it came to pass at the end of twenty years when Solomon had built the house of the LORD and the king's house (1 Kings 9:10). This long period reflects the extensive work required for God's temple and royal residence, paralleling other biblical building narratives (Exodus 25-40; Nehemiah 6:15-16; 2 Chronicles 3:1).

questions.question: What was Hiram king of Tyre's reaction to the cities Solomon gave him?
options: He was displeased and called them 'the land of Cabul'
He was pleased and praised Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: He was displeased and called them 'the land of Cabul'
questions.explanation: Hiram came to see the cities but they pleased him not, and he called the land of Cabul to this day (1 Kings 9:12-13). This shows political tension despite alliance, reminiscent of complex foreign relations in biblical history (2 Samuel 8:1; 1 Kings 5:1-12; Ezekiel 28:12-19).

questions.question: What reason does the chapter give for Solomon's levy or forced labor?
options: To build the house of the LORD, his own house, Millo, and fortifications
To serve as priests in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: To build the house of the LORD, his own house, Millo, and fortifications
questions.explanation: The levy was raised for building the temple, Solomon's palace, Millo, and the walls of Jerusalem plus other cities (1 Kings 9:15). This reflects the burden of labor required for national projects, similar to forced labor in Egypt (Exodus 1:11) and Solomon’s reign (2 Chronicles 2:17-18).

questions.question: Which king took Gezer and gave it to Solomon's wife as a present?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh king of Egypt
questions.explanation: Pharaoh king of Egypt captured Gezer, burned it, killed the Canaanites, and gave it as a present to his daughter, Solomon's wife (1 Kings 9:16). This political alliance through marriage highlights international diplomacy in biblical narratives (Genesis 12:16; 2 Samuel 3:3; Esther 2:16).

questions.question: What kind of service did Solomon impose on the remaining Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites?
questions.correctAnswer: Tribute of bondservice (forced labor)
questions.explanation: Solomon imposed a tribute of bondservice on the remaining non-Israelite peoples in the land whom Israel could not fully destroy (1 Kings 9:20-21). This reflects biblical themes of subjugation of conquered peoples (Numbers 33:50-56; Joshua 11:23; 2 Chronicles 8:7-9).

questions.question: How did Solomon treat the children of Israel in relation to bondservice?
options: He made no bondmen of the children of Israel
He subjected them to the same bondservice
He sent them as envoys to other nations
questions.correctAnswer: He made no bondmen of the children of Israel
questions.explanation: Solomon did not make Israelites bondmen but used them as warriors, servants, princes, captains, and rulers (1 Kings 9:22). This distinction highlights God's covenant people’s special status, consistent with God’s law forbidding Israelites to be slaves to each other (Leviticus 25:39-42; Exodus 21:2-6; Deuteronomy 15:12-18).

questions.question: How many chief officers did Solomon appoint over the laborers working on his projects?
questions.correctAnswer: Five hundred and fifty
questions.explanation: Solomon appointed 550 chief officers to oversee the workers on his building projects (1 Kings 9:23). This shows organized administrative structure similar to other biblical examples of large-scale labor management (Exodus 18:21-23; Nehemiah 3:16; 2 Chronicles 2:2).

questions.question: Where did Pharaoh's daughter dwell after coming up from the city of David?
options: In the house Solomon built for her
questions.correctAnswer: In the house Solomon built for her
questions.explanation: Pharaoh's daughter came up from the city of David to the house Solomon built for her, after which Solomon built Millo (1 Kings 9:24). This reflects royal marriage customs and palace construction (Genesis 24:67; 1 Kings 3:1; Esther 2:16).

questions.question: How often did Solomon offer burnt offerings and peace offerings upon the altar he built to the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Three times a year
questions.explanation: Solomon offered burnt and peace offerings three times annually on the altar he built, also burning incense before the LORD (1 Kings 9:25). This corresponds with the biblical festival calendar (Exodus 23:14-17; Leviticus 23; Deuteronomy 16:16).

questions.question: Where did Solomon build a navy of ships?
options: Eziongeber, beside Eloth on the Red Sea shore
questions.correctAnswer: Eziongeber, beside Eloth on the Red Sea shore
questions.explanation: Solomon built a navy at Eziongeber, near Eloth on the Red Sea, in the land of Edom (1 Kings 9:26). This demonstrates Israel’s expansion into maritime trade, consistent with biblical themes of commerce and wealth (Genesis 37:28; Jonah 1:3; Acts 27:2).

questions.question: Who accompanied Solomon's servants on the navy ships to Ophir?
options: Hiram’s shipmen who had knowledge of the sea
questions.correctAnswer: Hiram’s shipmen who had knowledge of the sea
questions.explanation: Hiram sent his servants, skilled shipmen, to accompany Solomon's servants on the navy (1 Kings 9:27). This alliance brought expert maritime knowledge, aiding Israel’s trade, reflecting biblical cooperation between nations (1 Kings 5:6-12; Ezekiel 27:8; Acts 21:3).

questions.question: How much gold did the fleet bring back from Ophir to King Solomon?
questions.correctAnswer: Four hundred and twenty talents
questions.explanation: The fleet fetched 420 talents of gold from Ophir and brought it to Solomon (1 Kings 9:28). This enormous wealth highlights Solomon’s prosperity and God's blessing, paralleling Solomon's wisdom and riches (2 Chronicles 9:13-14; Psalm 72:10-15; Proverbs 3:13-16).
